Sure, here are some other tips for growing a sustainable garden:

1. Choose native plants: Native plants are adapted to your climate and soil, and therefore require less water, fertilizer, and pest control than other plants.

2. Compost: Composting is a great way to reduce food waste and create nutrient-rich soil for your garden. Using compost instead of chemical fertilizers, encourages healthy soil and minimizes additions of synthetic chemicals or fertilizers.

3. Use rainwater: Collect rainwater and use it to water your plants. Rainwater is usually free of the chemicals that are added to tap water to purify it.

4. Avoid synthetic fertilizers and pesticides: Synthetic fertilizers and pesticides can damage the soil, water quality and harm beneficial insects, pollinators, and other wildlife. Choose eco-friendly alternatives whenever possible.

5. Use efficient watering techniques: Use drip irrigation or soaker hoses to deliver water directly to the roots of plants, which can be up to 90% more efficient than sprinklers.

6. Harvest rainwater: Attach a rain barrel to the downspout on your home or garden shed to collect roof runoff for your garden.

Remember, a sustainable garden makes healthy soil through responsible gardening practices, meaning your garden can produce productive, healthier plants, while minimizing environmental harm.
